title: When Large Language Models Meet Speech: A Survey on Integration Approaches
author: Zhengdong Yang (Kyoto University), Shuichiro Shimizu (Kyoto University), Yahan Yu (Kyoto University), Chenhui Chu (Kyoto University), ...
relevance_why: This survey directly relates to the integration of Large Language Models (LLMs) with speech, a crucial area for my research in audio processing. The insights on different integration approaches can inform my methods for audio generation and enhancement.
background: The paper reviews various methodologies for integrating speech with LLMs, including text-based, latent-representation-based, and audio-token-based approaches.
contribution: This survey introduces three main integration approaches to solve the challenge of utilizing speech with LLMs, achieving a structured overview of the state of the art.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous studies provide focused insights on either speech or language models but lack a comprehensive view of integration methods.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work systematically categorizes integration techniques, offering a clear framework for understanding advancements and future challenges.

key_innovation: The paper's unique categorizations provide a roadmap for researchers to identify areas for innovation in the intersection of speech and language models.
real_world_impact: By clarifying integration methods, this survey can guide future development of more capable speech and language processing systems, which can enhance user interactions in applications like virtual assistants and automated transcription.
limitations: No limitations are explicitly mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.latent-representation-based integration: **Latent-representation-based integration** refers to the method of using internal, lower-dimensional representations of speech data to connect with LLMs, allowing for a more accurate processing of speech.
new_terms.audio-token-based integration: **Audio-token-based integration** involves using tokens derived from audio signals to directly interface with LLMs, facilitating a more refined approach compared to traditional discrete text methods.
